runs.text: Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this story is about a boy who helps his aunt, a scientist who works at a lab. Use the illustrations to help students understand what a scientist does in a lab. Explain that when a person gives a helpful hand, he or she gives assistance or helps out in some way.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to help someone else do a task or job.
your family with tasks, or jobs, at home? Tell your partner about them.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that describes the things Aunt Sofia removes from water. (harmful)
What is the first thing the boy and his aunt do at the lab? Find the sentence that answers the question.
or help, his aunt? If you know
means to help, what do you think an assistant is? Why does the boys aunt describe him as a very helpful lab assistant?
If you visited a lab, what would you want to explore? Explain your answer.
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Explain that this text is a photo comic. It has panels and text boxes like a comic, but it features photos and facts instead of illustrations and dialogue for a story. Tell students that this text tells about viruses, tiny germs that can make us sick.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the comic.
means so small that it can only be seen with a microscope.
: The cells that make up our bodies are
you would like to see under a microscope.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Find the word that includes the suffix
and tells how strong viruses are. (powerful)
What happens when a virus invades, or takes over, the cells of living things? Find the sentence that answers this question.
How can scientists learn about viruses if they are microscopic
or too small to be seen with our eyes? Do you think scientists should try to get rid of every virus that exists on Earth? Why or why not?
Some viruses are germs that can make people sick. What can you do at school and home to avoid getting sick from a virus?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Have students whisper-read each sentence. Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with the suffixes
Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
Have students read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the related words that form phrases in sentences 3, 4, and 8.
Model how to chunk the text into meaningful phrases as you read each sentence, such as separating the subject and the predicate.
Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your phrasing.

Read the title, modeling appropriate intonation. Point out that the title includes two exclamation points. Explain that this text features brain teasers. Brain teasers are like riddles: readers must use the clues to figure out the word that answers each question.

For the first reading, have students read the question, while you read the answer. Then pair students to reread the brain teasers. Partners can switch roles during the rereadingsone asks the question and the other answers it.
Prompt students to find words with the suffix
in the brain teasers and circle them. Then have students chorally read the circled words. Ask students questions about the text to confirm understanding.
Say each word, guide students to write it, then proceed to the next word in the sentence.
Provide supports for words that are completely comprised of the phonics skills students have learned.
These supports include sound boxes, tapping the sounds, and so on.
Provide supports for the high-frequency words students have learned.
When completed, have students read the entire sentence aloud.
Self-Correct: Write the sentences on the board, and have students self-correct. Take note of errors on each students Student Observation Form.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word. Point out the question mark and note that the title asks a question.
Point to the scale. Explain that we use a scale to determine how much something weighs. Ask students to point to the objects on the scale and name them. Ask them which object weighs more.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
means to carefully study something so you can understand it.
: To correctly solve a riddle, you must
Ask: How does a doctor or dentist
you? Why do they need to carefully study your body or teeth?
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
Besides warning readers not to answer too soon, what does the author say they should be? Find the word. (careful)
What makes this brain teaser tricky? Find the sentence that answers this question.
What tips does the author give to help you analyze
or carefully examine, brain teasers and riddles? Why might following these steps make it easier to come up with the correct answer?
Do you find solving brain teasers fun or frustrating? Explain your answer.
Then ask them to chorally read it.
Have students circle words with the suffixes
. Have them point to and read those words to a partner.
Have students write a sentence using the word
. Have them read the sentence to a partner.
Discuss the different end punctuation for sentences 3 (period), 4 (question mark), and 5 (exclamation point).
Model how you change your intonation when reading a question (raise voice at end) or an exclamation (read with excitement).
Have students echoread the sentences, replicating your intonation.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.

Point out the exclamation point. Ask students what they noticed when you read the title aloud. Explain that this text compares the weights of balls used in different sports. Remind students that when we compare, we look at things and think about how they are alike and different.

Point out that this text includes graphics. Explain that authors include graphics to help readers quickly grasp information. These graphics show the number of each type of ball that equals ten pounds.
Guide students through a reading of the selection, including the graphic.
Prompt students to share what they notice and wonder when viewing the graphic.

Read the title, and have students repeat as they say each word. This is an on-level selection. It is provided to gauge where students are in their reading progress toward grade-level goals. Students might need to listen and follow along with the e-book for support before they read the book on their own.

Explain to students that they will read about two states of matter: solids and liquids. Point to examples of each in the photos, name them, and identify each one as a solid or a liquid. Ask students to name other examples of solids and liquids.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the text.
is anything that has weight and takes up space.
Have students whisper-read the text. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
What can change part of an orange into orange juice? Find a phrase that answers the question. (powerful squeeze)
What are two forms of matter that an orange can take? Find the sentences that answer this question.
According to the text, what are two ways matter can change from a solid to a liquid? Why do you think liquid water can change into solid ice in winter?
What other solids and liquids do you know about? Which ones can you change from a solid to a liquid? From a liquid to a solid? How?
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
Read the title, and have students repeat as they point to each word.
Explain that this story is about a woman who travels to new planets with her pet cat. Use the illustrations to review the three states of matter with students before reading.
routine. You will prompt students to use this word to talk about the story.
means to cast something out because you do not like or want it.
the cookies because they had peanut butter in them.
: What is a food you would
? Why would you not want to eat it?
Have students whisperread the story. Circulate, listen in, and offer corrective feedback.
When completed, ask the following questions to check comprehension. Prompt students to answer each question with a partner before you call on volunteers to answer the question.
How does Professor Ott feel about finding other amazing planets? Find the word that answers the question. (hopeful)
What does Professor Ott find on the three planets she lands on? Find the sentences that answer the question.
the first planet? What does he dislike about the second planet?
Professor Ott says the search for a planet like Earth is fruitless. If the suffix
means without, what do you think the word
means in the story? Use clues in the text and pictures to help you determine the words meaning.
If you could visit any planet in our solar system, which one would you like to visit? What would make you
Have students reread the book during independent work time and as a warm-up to the next days lesson.
